H0.text: Hypha is the structure from which conidiospores, unicellular or multicellular asexual spores, are released directly from the tip or side.

H1.text: Ganglion is the structure from which unicellular or multicellular conidiospores, a type of asexual spore, are released directly from the tip or side.

H2.text: Idioma is the structure from which conidiospores, which are unicellular or multicellular asexual spores, are released directly from the tip or side.

H3.text: Goychay is the tip or side from which conidiospores—unicellular or multicellular asexual spores—are released.

A4.text: Conidiomata, such as pycnidia and acervuli, are the structures from which conidia are released through openings like the ostiole.

A5.text: Conidia are borne on specialized stalks called conidiophores, which are distinct from the hypha.

A6.text: Acervular conidiomata, or acervuli, are cushion-like structures that form within the tissues of a host organism: subcuticular, lying under the outer layer of the plant (the cuticle), intraepidermal, inside the outer cell layer (the epidermis), subepidermal, under the epidermis, or deeper inside the host. Mostly they develop a flat layer of relatively short conidiophores which then produce masses of spores.

A7.text: The conidial anastomosis tubes are morphologically and physiologically distinct from germ tubes. After conidia are induced to form conidial anastomosis tubes, they grow homing toward each other, and they fuse.
